item.title: Estimating Colony Forming Units (CFU) on a large plate.
item.author: Luis Cantu
item.description:
üìò Overview

Colony-forming unit (CFU) is a measurement of viable bacterial cells capable of forming a colony. Unlike total cell counts, CFU excludes dead cells and only reflects the number of living, reproductive units in a sample.

This protocol is a modified version of the Miles and Misra method, adapted for quick estimation from small glycerol stock volumes.

üìò Notes

  • Units:
    • CFU/mL for liquids
    • CFU/g for solids
  • This is a semi-quantitative method using ~2 cm streaks with a multichannel pipette.

ü¶† Part I ‚Äî Growing cells and layout

  1. Re-suspend glycerol stock

    • Glycerol stocks are stored in 10 ŒºL aliquots.
    • Re-suspend one aliquot in 1000 ŒºL of 2√óYT media.

  2. Heatshock cells

    • Incubate at 50‚ÄØ¬∞C for 10 minutes.

  3. Prepare serial dilutions

    • In 10 PCR tubes, perform 10-fold serial dilutions:
      • Transfer 10 ŒºL of the original suspension into 90 ŒºL of fresh 2√óYT.
      • Label the tubes as 1, 10‚Åª¬π, 10‚Åª¬≤, …, 10‚Åª‚Åπ.

  4. Plate dilutions

    • Using a multichannel pipette, draw a ~2 cm streak of 10 ŒºL from each dilution onto an ISP2 agar plate supplemented with appropriate antibiotics if needed. See the example below in Step 5.

  5. Incubate

    • Grow the plates overnight at 30 ¬∞C.

    Note: In the example below we’ve plated in triplicate the same strain. Each column has dilutions from top to bottom: 1, 10‚Åª¬π, 10‚Åª¬≤, …, 10‚Åª‚Åπ. Be careful not to plate too close to the edges of the plate to avoid edge distortion.

Part II ‚Äî Cell counting and CFU determination

  1. Identify the readable dilution

    • Look for the dilution that gives individual colonies (typically 3‚Äì5).

  2. Count colonies & calculate CFU/mL
    Use the formula:

$$ \text{CFU/mL} = \frac{\text{Number of colonies} \times \text{Dilution Factor}}{\text{Volume plated (mL)}} $$

üßÆ Example Calculation

If 5 colonies grew on the 10‚Åª‚Å∏ dilution line, then:

$$ \begin{aligned} \text{CFU/mL} &= \frac{5 \times 10^8}{0.01} \ &= 5 \times 10^{10} , \text{CFU/mL} \end{aligned} $$

‚ö†Ô∏è Note: Since only a small streak was plated, this value provides an order of magnitude estimate, not a precise count.

‚úÖ Tips

  • Make sure your streaks are consistent in length and volume.
  • Always include a negative control plate (just 2√óYT).
  • Plates with <30 or >300 colonies are generally not used for accurate quantification in full CFU counting methods‚Äîbut this method is for quick estimation.

item.title: Conjugation in Streptomyces coelicolor
item.author: Luis Cantu
item.description:
Streptomyces Conjugation Protocol

Updated 23 Nov, 2023

Day 1

  1. Prepare competent cells of E. coli ET12567/pUZ8002 grown at 37¬∞C in LB containing:

    • Kanamycin (25 Œºg/ml)
    • Chloramphenicol (25 Œºg/ml)
      These maintain selection for pUZ8002 and the dam mutation, respectively.
      Note: ET12567 has a doubling time > 30 min. High competence is required when Dam-methylated plasmids are introduced into a dam‚Åª strain.

  2. Transform competent cells with the oriT-containing cosmid clone, and select for the incoming plasmid only using appropriate antibiotics (e.g., apramycin 50 Œºg/ml).

Day 2

  1. Inoculate a colony into 10 mL (or 5 mL) LB containing:
    • Chloramphenicol (25 Œºg/ml)
    • Kanamycin (25 Œºg/ml)
    • Apramycin (50 Œºg/ml, if needed)
      Grow overnight at 37¬∞C.

Day 3

  1. Inoculate 500 ŒºL of overnight culture into 10 mL fresh LB + antibiotics as above. Grow for ~4 hours at 37¬∞C until OD‚ÇÜ‚ÇÄ‚ÇÄ ‚âà 0.4.

  2. Wash the cells twice (spin at 3500 rpm for 10 min) with 10 mL LB to remove antibiotics. Resuspend in 1 mL LB.

  3. While washing E. coli, prepare Streptomyces spores:

    • Add 10 ŒºL (~10‚Å∏ spores) to 500 ŒºL 2√óYT broth.
    • Heat shock at 50¬∞C for 10 min, then let cool.

  4. Mix 0.5 mL E. coli and 0.5 mL heat-shocked spores.

    • Spin briefly (5000 rpm, 5 min).
    • Pipette off most supernatant and resuspend the pellet in ~50 ŒºL remaining liquid.

  5. Make a dilution series from 10‚Åª¬π to 10‚Åª‚Å¥, each in 100 ŒºL autoclaved water.

  6. Plate 100 ŒºL of each dilution onto MS agar + 10 mM MgCl‚ÇÇ + 60 mM CaCl‚ÇÇ (no antibiotics).

    • Incubate at 30¬∞C for 16‚Äì20 h.

Day 4

  1. Overlay each plate with 1 mL water containing:
    • 0.5 mg Nalidixic acid (20 ŒºL of 25 mg/mL stock)
    • 1.25 mg Apramycin (25 ŒºL of 50 mg/mL stock)
      Distribute the antibiotic solution evenly using a spreader in the hood.
      Continue incubation at 30¬∞C.

üí° This method allows efficient transfer of cosmids into Streptomyces by interspecies conjugation using methylation-deficient E. coli donors.
